comments.message: Uploaded patch set 1.

Patch Set 1: Ok-To-Test+1

User approved, CI ok to start

Patch Set 1: Verified+1

Build Successful 

https://jenkins.openbmc.org/job/ci-repository/26406/ : SUCCESS

Patch Set 1:

What's the plan here?

Patch Set 1:

> Patch Set 1:
> 
> What's the plan here?

To call it a "plan" is a bit extreme, and implies that I've thought this through, but at the moment, this requires us to pull the asio maintainers feature branch to compile and work
https://github.com/chriskohlhoff/asio/tree/io-uring-1

So if this is something we want badly, we need to decide if we:
1. Are ok pointing yocto at a non-master version of asio, under the assumption that the maintainer is pretty likely to get his own branch merged.
2. Want to help chriskohlhoff to develop and get this merged into boost 1.79 (already too late for 1.78)

I'm not sure I have a strong opinion on which.  At the moment this is mostly just an experiment to see what gains we get from io_uring in terms of latency and "pausing".

Patch Set 17: Code-Review+2

(1 comment)
Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as 16966b5586260a285097c2c2ce8b565e1d212edd

I have seen some intermittent invalid reading from CPUSensor service with my test. Does this change affect all boost async read/write calls? I have not isolate to this change only yet, but wanted to give a heads-up and also understand the scope of the change.

yes, it changes the underlying reactor, but I'd be surprised if it had any specific effects.  What might be happening is that things that were previously serial are now parallel, it exposed a timing bug?

If you disable these build options on cpusensor only, does the issue go away?
I ask the question because maybe a path forward would be to leave CPUSensor running in epoll mode until we can debug the issue, but move the rest of them forward.
ACK. I will test with CPUSensor running in epoll
I have tested with CPUSensor running in epoll and issue went away. No issues were observed from other services. @Ed will you make the change?

Sure.  Happy to.  Can you please file a github bug with a title of something like "CPUSensor locks up when used with io_uring" and include the details you found from your testing so we can track this to conclusion.  I would expect CPUsensor needs io_uring as well.
created https://github.com/openbmc/dbus-sensors/issues/19
Done
I noted this in the patchset.
\n
Ack
is it possible for this to return part of the data, which will result in wrong data value?
I don't believe so.  The hwmon interface I believe guarantees that the whole value will be returned on a single read.
Ack
bufferRef
ACK.  FWIW, this code is completely changing in the next patch to not rely on std::stoi (usese from_chars instead).  But sure, i'm happy to make this patch correct.  ACK.
Can you please share the next patch?

It's next in the series above, but yes, here's the link:
https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/dbus-sensors/+/55041/2
Done
\n
Ack
not used, is it only for keeping buffer alive until the callback?
Correct.
Ack
We need this patch... @All can we get this merged ?
Trying to get there;  We're waiting on issues with the Intel CPUSensor implementation locking up, which I'm assuming you're aware of?  (just based on your email address domain).
Done
Is the reference `&` accidentally removed?
Yes it was.  Good catch.
Done

This has been in review for a long time, been tested on several systems, and seems to be working.  Messages have been sent to discord asking about how best to roll this out, and most of the suggestions have been followed.  Merging.

Please make us aware of any issues.
